comment._content: Clara Washington Lopp alias Lady Nicotine, goddess of pipe dreams, see the New-York tribune., January 23, 1915, Page 9, with photo. She was a nurse at front and collected 45'185 pounds of tobacco for the allied soldiers. In may 1916, her husband George Washington Lopp attacked her and the stepdaughter after a quarrel and beated both into unconsciousness, see The evening world., May 16, 1916, Final Edition, Image 3. The article says that Lopp made a fortune as professional dancing master in Paris, where he introduced the cakewalk. His wife was the daughter of the Paraguayan Minister to Paris. See also New-York tribune., May 16, 1916, Page 3 About Lopp's carreer as dancing master: The Salt Lake tribune., December 10, 1911, Second News Section, Image 17, with photo.

comment._content: This photo was apparently taken on their arrival from France aboard the French Line's SS Espagne. An account of their arrival with daughter Sofia, as well as their activities (Mr. Lopp was a Red Cross official and she was Lady Nicotine) is in the December 16, 1915 New York Herald. fultonhistory.com/Newspaper%2014/New%20York%20NY%20Herald...

comment._content: George W. Lopp died in 1955, age 90, "one of the oldest Americans living in Paris": select.nytimes.com/gst/abstract.html?res=9901E6DA113EE63B... Sophia (Sofia) Machain, stepdaughter of George W. Lopp, married photographer James Slevin in May 1916, in Paris--because Lopp was considered violent, Slevin got a gun permit in time for the civil wedding ceremony: chroniclingamerica.loc.gov/lccn/sn83030214/1916-05-18/ed-... www.slavens.net/news/fiancee_attacked.htm query.nytimes.com/gst/abstract.html?res=F20E1FF93D5F13738...
